awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Constructal Theory for Evolutionary Design of Twisted Paths in Heat Transfer Network
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the present project is to derive a new theory for the design of heat transfer systems with twisted paths, a theory capable to analyze and predict the architecture of the heat transfer system with reduced thermal resistance, reduced pumping energy requirements, lower conductive material consumption, and consequently lower cost. The design methodology considers two geometric degrees of freedom: (1) hierarchy of components, that is, few large & many small, and (2) geometrical twist of the main energy paths. These aim to reduce the global thermal resistance to energy flow. If successful, the project can impact the cost of many energy systems by reducing their thermal resistance, pumping energy requirements, and conductive material consumption. The design methodology presented in this project has the potential to accelerate heat transfer technology evolution ranging from aerospace to biomedical systems. This project involves a postdoctoral scholar and one undergraduate student is to be supported through the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) supplement program. 

This project contributes to the design of thermal management systems by creatively integrating theoretical and numerical approaches with the rigorous design principle of Constructal Law. The considered design system is a slender heat transfer component (fin, channel, etc.) and its unique geometrical form of twisted shape. This project advances the state-of-the-art of current constructal theories in thermal design by introducing the twisted geometry as a new degree of freedom in constructal design. This  new transformative consideration can allow the design to morph and evolve more easily, yielding a high-risk/high-payoff condition if successful.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The wings of flying animals flex and morph during flight. Their wings morph with the turbulent flow created around them. However, modern airplane wings lack this capability [1].

We explored this phenomenon in nature from the perspective of constructal law. Nature follows this law when it comes to evolution. It was discovered by Prof. Adrian Bejan in 1996 and states "For a finite-size flow system to persist in time (to live), its configuration must evolve freely such that it provides greater access to its currents" [2,3].

In this law, the design is considered a physics principle, which allows us to predict the configuration and design. It is crucial to predict nature when designing hypersonic vehicles and space travel, because humans cannot mimic natural designs [4].

Flows and flow systems are key concepts in constructal law when looking at a system. There are several ways to describe flow, including what the flow carries (fluid, heat, mass, stress, etc.), how much it carries (flow rate, current, traffic, etc.), and where it is located (its configuration and location). From the constructal law, constructal theories revolve around the where [2,5-8].

Bejan et al. [3] introduced the concept of "flow of stresses". As they showed, the avoidance of flow strangulation is the universal principle that accounts for both the configuration of heat and fluid flow and the configuration of stress flow. They studied solid structures where stresses flow without strangulation by viewing solid structures as flow systems that configure and morph. Thus, such structures are the strongest and lightest [1,9].

This project clarifies that if the flow of stresses is not strangled, the stability boundary of Fluid-Structure Interaction (FSI) systems increases. The aeroelastic (FSI) design of airplane wings returns favor to the animal design by revealing the physics of the wing that flexes (curves and twitches). 

As the wing morphs (curves) with freedom, the stresses are distributed throughout its body uniformly at all times. It allows the wing to be the lightest per unit of flapping force, or the strongest per unit of weight, Fig.1-2. 

Another outcome proceeds from the addition of the other degrees of freedom for the curvature in the flow of stresses in the plane of the wing cross-section. According to the same approach, less stress strangulation leads to a higher stability boundary [10-13], Fig.3.

The project involved an associate professor, a postdoctoral fellow, and two graduate students. Four [1,9-11,14] journal articles and one conference paper [11] were published in peer-reviewed journals and proceedings. Three more conference papers [12-13,15] have been accepted for publication. 

References:

  1. Mardanpour, P., Izadpanahi, E., Powell, S., Rastkar, S. and Bejan, A., 2021. Inflected wings in flight: uniform flow of stresses makes strong and light wings for stable flight. Journal of Theoretical Biology, 508, p.110452.
  2. Bejan, A. and Lorente, S., 2013. Constructal law of design and evolution: Physics, biology, technology, and society. Journal of Applied Physics, 113(15), p.6.
  3. Bejan, A. and Lorente, S., 2008. Design with constructal theory.
  4. Mardanpour, P., 2020. Freedom and Evolution: Hierarchy in Nature, Society, and Science.
  5. Bejan, A., 1997. Constructal-theory network of conducting paths for cooling a heat generating volume. International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer, 40(4), pp.799-816.
  6. Bejan, A., 2000. Shape and structure, from engineering to nature. Cambridge university press.
  7. Bejan, A. and Lorente, S., 2011. The constructal law and the evolution of design in nature. Physics of life Reviews, 8(3), pp.209-240.
  8. Bejan, A. and Zane, J.P., 2013. Design in Nature: How the Constructal Law governs evolution in biology, physics, technology, and social organizations. Anchor.
  9. Izadpanahi, E., Rastkar, S. and Mardanpour, P., 2019. Constructal design of flying wing aircraft: curved and swept configurations. AIAA Journal, 57(12), pp.5527-5542.
  10. Moshtaghzadeh, M., Izadpanahi, E., Bejan, A. and Mardanpour, P., 2022. Evolutionary Aeroelastic Design of Flying-Wing Cross Section. AIAA Journal, 60(2), pp.913-924.
  11. Moshtaghzadeh, M., Izadpanahi, E., Bejan, A. and Mardanpour, P., 2022. Aeroelastic Stability and Flow of Stresses in Wing Cross-Section. In AIAA SCITECH 2022 Forum (p. 0536).
  12. Moshtaghzadeh, M., Bejan. A., Mardanpour. P., 2022. An Evolutionary Aeroelastic Design Approach for Spars and Ribs of Flyingwing Aircraft. In  ASME (IMECE2022)
  13. Moshtaghzadeh, M., Bejan, A. and Mardanpour, P., 2023. An Evolutionary Aeroelastic Design Approach for Spar and Rib Configuration of Flying Wing Aircraft. In AIAA SCITECH 2023 Forum
  14. Moshtaghzadeh, M., Bakhtiari, A. and Mardanpour, P., 2022. Artificial Neural Network-based Finite Element method for assessing fatigue and stability of an origami-inspired structure. Engineering Structures, 272, p.114965.
  15. Moshtaghzadeh, M., Rangel, N. and Mardanpour, P., 2023. Constitutive and Geometric Effects on Nonlinear Aeroelastic Trim and Stability of the Predator Aircraft. In AIAA SCITECH 2023 Forum
